history.text: Jaws has a rating of 8/10 on IMDb. Did you agree with that high rating?
Yes, an 8/10 rating sounds accurate from the interpretation of the critics.
What do you think about the suspense of this movie?
It was thrilling, but also funny. The humor helped ease the suspense.
I also like the humor aspect of a thriller.  The anxiety makes the funny scenes much more enjoyable
What do you think about the comparison to Woody Allen?
I don't agree with that comparison. I wonder if that was a review written in the 70s, because I didn't see the Jaws humor as being so verbal as Allen's.
Did you think Jaws was exploitative?

I completely agree with you about the Woody Allen comment.  I don't see it, either.  The idea of Jaws can be a bit exploitative.  The idea of an evil, killer shark is not completely realistic to every day life.  There are such a small percentage of shark attacks, and the shark is often not trying to kill the person.
That is a very good point.
If a person were watching Jaws in our time period, do you think the comment "too gruesome for children" would still apply?
I think so, because of the jump scare with the head.
Yeah, me too.  I want my kids to be interested in swimming and the ocean.  I think a killer shark would freak them out.

The horror genre has been very influenced by the conflict between the sheriff and the mayor. That was one of the best parts about the plot to me, the frustration, and I guess the dramatic irony of knowing how bad the shark is from the beginning.
Yes, the best movies have those great character struggles.  The acting also helps make those feelings known.
Who is your favorite actor in Jaws?
Definitely Robert Shaw. When he got everyone's attention during the meeting...what a way to introduce a character!
Great choice.  I am partial to Richard Dreyfuss, but I feel that there are many greats in the line-up.
It is hard to believe this movie came out in 1975.

I love that scene with Dreyfus and Shaw singing. Yes, it really holds up well. I actually saw it for the first time this summer in a re-release in the theater and it was just as good as any modern horror to me.
I was going to say that it would be fun to watch in the theater.  I would be interested to see it in a re-release.  It would be a blast.
It is amazing what can be done with suspense without using gore and buckets of blood.
My dad screamed and spilled his popcorn when the head floated up.
That's awesome.  It has just enough details to cause that reaction without making you want to throw up.
Spielberg had a perfect balance.
It's easy to forget how good Spielberg is, I guess I take him for granted. Jaws gave me a new appreciation, you could see how he got so huge.

Yes.  I have taken film class, and we had the opportunity to make a few films.  You can really see the wonderful techniques that someone like Spielberg adopted.  The angles, music, and various other aspects keep the viewer intense.
They really got creative with all the ways they tried to kill the shark at the end!
What angles did he use that were unique in Jaws?
Ooo, there is a review on this document that says we don't feel sympathy for the victims. I don't agree with that.
One example of the filming was the boy on the beach.  Spielberg is capturing the whole scene of the beach, but he is following the boy at the same time.
Yeah, it is hard to not feel for the victim.  It would not put us personally in the movie if we could not relate to the characters.
I'm going to have to watch this again.
Me too.
